Description: Egyptian terracotta mould-made pottery vessel with the mouth and neck in the shape of upper part of a nude female with arms upraised, grasping her hair. The head and kalathos headdress is the cylindrical mouth and the pose suggests this is an Egyptian interpretation of a representation of Aphrodite. Well modelled, front and back. Hollow, from a two-piece mould. Pale red clay.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Naukratis (Bailey 2008, 3506; GR 1886,0401.1430 ) has been dated to the 3rd or 2nd centuries BC, partially based on a comparison with a faience head in the British Museum, probably of Berenike II or Arsinoe III, with a closely similar kalathos flask-mouth (GR 2001, 0129.3 Thompson 1973: pl. lxiv:273). Fairbanks, A.1928, Catalogue of Greek and Etruscan Vases, Boston. Thompson, D.B. 1973. ‘Ptolemaic Oinochoai and Portraits in Faience’. Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 135, pl. XL, no. 379.2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.608) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5847 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
